title: Airsoft M41A Pulse Rifle Magazine Mod

description.text:
this modification lets you attach the M41A magwell cap to the Thompson Magazine so that it looks a little more like it did in the movie.

update: the "all in one" V2.5 has been updated to V2.6 but i have not tried printing it yet.
"all in one" v1.5 has been printed and tested, and i would recommend using this version of it.

notes for all files:

  1. you will need slightly longer screws for the side pieces (1 or 1.5mm longer then the ones that are in the cap's thumb pads)
  2. cut off the locking tabs on the thumb pads, because you will have a extra hard to remove Magazine if you don't.

notes for the lose "side" and "bottom" parts:

  1. you will need to mirror the side part to make one for the other side.
  2. make and put the bottom part into the cap first.

title: LCD Panel Face Plate & Bracket for Folger Tech Kossel 2020

description.text:
I liked the LCD bracket I made for my Prusa i3v & remixed it to work with my Folger Tech Kossel 2020.

This is remixed from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1276141

I would suggest you print FT_LCD_FacePlateTest_Rev11.stl before printing the faceplate or all the parts to make sure it fits. I had one LCD display that was a little crooked & had to adjust the opening for the display slightly.

For your final prints you will need to print either the FT_LCD_AllParts_Rev11.stl or

FT_LCD_FacePlate_Rev11.stl
FT_LCD_LeftAndRightBrackets_Rev11.stl
FT_LCD_TopCoverPlate_Rev11.stl
FT_LCD_4x_Spacers_Rev11.stl

For Hardware you will need:
4 M3x16mm socket head or Pan Head screws to mount faceplate to Brackets
2 M3x16mm socket head or Pan Head screws to mount Top Cover plate to Brackets
2 or 4 M3x8mm screws & T-Nuts to mount to 2020 Aluminum
(I had enough of the M3x8mm & T-Nuts left over from the build)

While installing these parts, I realized I should have made the slots for the Right & Left bracket so they would slide onto the bolts in 1 direction. I added that change to the parts I uploaded. The left bracket I made the slotted opening with .3mm plastic bottom which printed better for me. I just had to cut that out with a small pair of wire cutters.

There is also an openscad file you can edit in case you want to change something else about this design.

I printed these parts at 20% infill in yellow PETG. I added enough photos that should show you how to assemble these parts.

description.text:
This is a prototype humanoid arm development robot platform. Our intent is to make a platform with the "function over form" mind set. Feel free to comment, change, improve or add on to our designs. These are free for everyone to use for educational and non-commercial applications. We hope to gain a good understanding of the motions that are required for a proper arm robot platform. We hope to mimic the human structure as much as possible in terms of motion. Upon completion we will move onto Mark 2 which would have thought for different types of actuators, components, electronics and batteries. A few disclaimers for those of you attempting to print this thing.
  • It has not been printed on our side yet - therefore - have fun
  • This is not a final version - this is Mark 1 a.k.a. v1.0 alpha
  • No thought was put in for servos, motors, muscle wire, air muscle or any other actuator
  • The Animusoft Corporation cannot be held liable for any damages that may be incurred
    • For more information about Animusoft check out our website @ http://www.animusoft.com

print_settings.Notes:: This was printed with E3D's White Edge (PETG) filament as well.

description.text:
Easy and quick to print (about 3.5 hours) and easy to install. I aimed to design something simple that did the job it needed to do while having a clean and attractive appearance. I use a modified Hictop Prusa i3 but this should fit on nearly any Prusa i3 that uses block bearings.

!!Important!! Make sure that when you place the model in your slicer that it is flat on the bed. It is ever so slightly off axis, and honestly I don't know how to fix it at the moment.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I wanted to create something clean and simple to mount E3D's Titan extruder to my printer. It uses very little plastic, is easy to install, fits great, and in most cases gives a little extra space to your Z axis.

This was printed with E3D's White Edge (PETG) filament as well.

Installation

Print 2 of the Titan Adapter V2 Belt Att. This will fit in the gaps on the back of the carriage very snugly. I recommend a little big of crazy glue inside and it won't go anywhere.

I use Shuttl3d's fan setup for E3Dv6, which can be found here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:510957

E3D's Titan assembly can be found here - http://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/Titan_Assembly

For those first time Titan installs, the extrusion rate multiplier is about 3.8. You'll also probably have to reverse the direction of the extruder motor either by reversing a pair of wires (Don't forget to unplug your power before unplugging/ pluggin in stepper motors!!) or adjusting settings in firmware
I designed and rendered this using Fusion 360. I pulled many of the models from Grabcad to aid in development and ensure a proper fit. Tolerances are built in so screws fit properly.

comments.text: HI, very nice light weight mount but the belt clamps do not fit GT-2 belts, which is what most printers use.  I can email a modified version if you'd like.
comments.author: RustyNails

comments.text: I use GT-2 as well.  I've found that it's not entirely necessary for the belts to fit really snug into grooves and that using zip ties to secure them is more than sufficient.  The way they pull on the clamps there isn't any way that they would come loose,  I've left well enough alone in this case.

This is a newer version of my hub adapter for Excelvan spools for use with the BobsCNC RP9 printer. The original can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1698289

I was dissatisfied with the visual artifacts caused by the fact that I created it with Tinkercad and, hence, the object had a lower poly count.

This model was created with 123D Design as an exercise in using a more advanced CAD tool. I doubt there is any benefit in printing this over my original but it might be prettier!

Doesn't Matter

No

0.2 mm

30%

Notes:

I use a raft just because it makes removing the adapter from the bed a bit easier. To each their own.

This is an easy print that nearly any printer should have no problems with. No supports are needed.

I've printed in PLA and it is flexible enough to move from one spool to the next but I'm sure that ABS would be more resilient.

title: Knurled knob for Malyan M150 bed levelling

description.text:
I recently bought a Malyan 3d printer, its my first. And while learning about how to use it and discovering the joys of prints not sticking at start and the importance of bed levelling I discovered the bed levelling knobs are hard to use. I downloaded and printed out another knurled knob but it fouled on the endplates for the Y axis. So I decide to make my own knob with a narrow profile to clear the Y axis endplates.

this knob is printed in two parts to enable the capture of the nut. I just paused the print job at the right moment and jogged the print head out of the way so that I could place the nuts in. Then I restarted the job and the print head went back to work and covered the nut in. Doing it this way caused a string to pull off the job. I just wiped the string away with my hand. Theirs probably a better way to pause mid job that will back the filament out and prevent stringing. If you know what it is please add to the comments.

The knurled nut works great on my new Malyan M150.

Added Version 2 update: - Version 2 includes dome above nut for better bridging across the steel nut by allowing the extrusion to build from the existing nut keeper sides.

See also the public link to Fusion 360 source files http://a360.co/2b31BRd

Creating a knurled nut in Fusion 360

I created this nut in Fusion 360.

I'll write a more detailed description of how I designed this nut later.

comments.text:
This is the only knob that worked well for me (Malayan M150). Dudsr's idea to pause the print to drop the nuts is a good one.
The hex hole seems to be larger than the M3 nut, but somehow the upper layers hold it together and avoid rotation/slipping (so far so good).
Many thanks!

QR Code 80 X 80 mm
Done on a Single extruder with two colors
See below for more details

The STL file here is just for displaying purposes, since the QR code will direct you to my class syllabus file. If you wish to 3D print it for testing purposes or for display, it's up to you. If you would like to make your own this is how I did mine:

Design process:
I used google drive to upload the pdf file version of my syllabus.
From google drive right click on the pdf file and share the pdf file as a web link, this step will give you a link that can be convereted to a QR code on the next step.
Google chrome has QR code generators extensions, or you can use any free QR code generator such as: www.qrstuff.com to create your QR code image. Save it as JPEG. ( I used the snipping tool to cut out the image and save it as JPEG to my computer.
Once you have saved the QR code image, use http://image.online-convert.com/ website
to convert your qr code image to an SVG file. CLICK THE ENHANCE OPTION before you hit the convert button.
Once you have the SVG file, import it as sketch or solid to your CAD program. I used 123 design and worked perfect. Keep in mind that the SVG file may appear as a super large size. You can scale it to your preference.
Make sure you make the proper extrusions to make it look like the original JPEG file you created with the QR code generator. Compared the 3D version and original JPEG before you save it as STL and print.
I designed the base and snapped the QR code to the. Make sure that the QR code is 3D printed in dark color (preferably) black for easy scanning. I have a single extruder printer and was able to print in two colors. I simply paused the printing process right after the base and the first two layers of the Qr code are completed then changed the filament to obtain the two color 3D printout.
I hope you enjoy this project. :)

title: Ice Drawer Handle for GE Profile Fridge

description.text: This handle/spacer slips over the front of the ice drawer in GE "Profile" Refrigerator with freezer on the bottom (PFSS2MIYI SS). It provides just the right spacing to close the ice drawer when the main freezer drawer is closed. All too often, when we got ice, we didn't push the ice drawer back in all the way. This prevented the ice maker from making more ice. Even worse, when the ice drawer is out just the right amount, the water would pour into the ice drawer instead of the ice maker. This spacer makes sure the ice drawer is closed when the main drawer is closed.

Infill:

I went with 12%.

Notes:

It would probably make the most sense to print this upside down so that no supports are needed.

After a while the original Techzone Huxley X carriage with a single bronze bushing started to get sticky, despite of any oil I fed it. It created some massive backlash on the X axis, so I designed this : Used to replace the original single bronze bushing X axis carriage with 3 LM6UU linear bearings. Includes holes for mounting a better attached hotend (with a peek block retaining the nozzle). Parts needed :
  • 1 printed X carriage (this file).
  • 3 x LM6UU
  • 2 x 6mm smooth rods, length 300mm (to replace non-metric original techzone X rods).
    • Based on PRUSA Mendel X-carriage by Josef PrÅ¯Å¡a The Openscad file, along with any dependencies needed, is in the zip archive. UPDATE
    Added ziptie holes to secure the linear bearings.

1) Print.
2) Fit the 2 belt attaching M3 bolts that goes under the LM6UU (might need to use the soldering iron to push those in).
3) Snap LM6UUs in - you might want to secure them using zip-ties so they don't move - I had to open holes with my dremel for that. Feel free to add holes to the design :)
4) Dismantle your X axis
5) Remount your X axis, replacing the 6.56mm non metric rods with 6mm ones and the old X carriage with this new one.

description.text:
glidecam-style stabilizer for gopro. made to use 4 common 608 skate bearings.

Hardware:
4X 608 skate bearings
1X threaded rod (6/32 used, max size is inner dia. of bearings (8mm), would need to 'cut' new hole in actual mount)
11X 6/32 nuts (3X if using different sized rod (and 8 of that size)
3X 6/32 machine screws (3/4 inch or longer)
11X #6 washers (stacked ones seen inside gimbal are needed if not cutting 15mm M3 screws to size)
7X M3 Machine screws (4X 30mm and 3X 15mm (may need to cut to specific lengths)

Optional (for outside bearings on gimbal (holes for screws included, not needed)):
2X #6 washers
2X M3 or 6/32 machine screws

You will likely need to figure out your own weight solution. mine is part of the iron core out of a small A/C motor.

Special Thanks:
'spinner.stl' is borrowed from 'Tiny Planetary Gears Set' by Aubenc: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23030 (crank_handle.stl)

'GoproMount.stl' is modified and borrowed from 'GoPro Extension (75 mm, straight)' by Hcc23: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454206 (Gopro_Extension_75.stl)

Thanks for downloading! Consider leaving a tip if you found it useful!

title: Davinci E3D mount with extruder upgrade

description.text:
Since my Davinci 1.0's stock extruder idler became worn down and unuseable, I've been looking for an alternative extruder but there aren't too many options out there.
I tried a printed extruder which uses a bearing as an idler which worked well but it means the extruder stepper is only attached to the carriage by 2 screws.
So I thought I'd have a go at designing a mod that incorporates the E3D hotend mount plus a replacement mk8 style extruder in one part making the whole thing much more secure.
The carriage is now much lighter without all that clunky metal.
I've tested it with various filaments including flexible and it's working great.
For anyone who has already done the E3D mod, it's a simple upgrade. You just need to dismantle the stock extruder and replace it with this.
If you're starting from scratch, this is much easier to fit that an E3D with the stock extruder.
I don't see any reason why it can't be used with other makes of printer.
I've also included an optional filament guide for printing with flexible filament.

Parts required :-

1 x bearing 3x10x5mm
2 x M3 screws 30mm
1 x M3 screw 25mm
2 x M3 screws 10mm
1 x compression spring 10mm diameter 16-20mm in length
Oh, and an E3D hotend of course.

Instructions :-

  1. Firstly, you’ll need to decide whether to do the mod with the carriage in place or remove it. I chose to leave it in place, it was a bit fiddly but probably saved a bit of time.
  2. Dismantle the stock extruder and bin all that metal junk !
  3. (Skip this step if you've already fitted an E3D.)
    Next, you need to raise the stepper mounting in order for the E3D to fit in the carriage. Use the template to drill the new screw holes in the carriage and cut the half circle for the stepper.
  4. Glue the spacer to the back of the mount across the top 2 screw holes. (Or you could just hold it in place before screwing the mount to the carriage.) The spacer will bridge the gap between the stepper and the top of the mount making the whole thing more secure.
  5. (Optional) Fit the filament guide to the end of the PTFE liner sticking out the top of the E3D. You need about 4mm of liner sticking out the top.
  6. Place the E3D in the mount (main and front piece) and fit it to the carriage with the 30mm screws in the bottom 2 screw holes and a 10mm screw in the top left.
  7. Fit the bearing to the lever with a 10mm screw, place the spring on the mount then screw the lever to the top right screw hole with the 25mm screw. You may need to push the lever down on the spring a bit to get it in place.
  8. Done !

Update - 23/8/2016

I've added a new version of the mount main part.
With the first version, there was a small gap of about 2-3mm between the lever and the mount due to the position of the spring.
I've tweaked the design to reduce the gap so that the lever can now fit right up against the mount.
This makes it much easier to fit the lever in the correct position and also makes it more secure.

Update - 29/8/2016

Ran into a problem with some flexible filament, there's too big a gap above the extruder gear causing it to buckle between the lever and the gear.
Easily fixed with a piece of PTFE tubing cut to a V shape at one end and pushed through the hole in the top of the lever (see picture above.)
You might need to drill the hole out a bit if it's too tight.

comments.text:
Do you believe a bearing that is 3x10x4 will work, maybe with a shim?
I hope so, I already ordered it!
It is the most common size I can find.
comments.author: larrynotlawrence

comments.text: Yeah, that should be fine.
comments.author: larrynotlawrence

comments.text:
Hello.
I really want to do this mod. Have an E3D and ready to go.
Problem is I can't find a 3x10x5 bearing. I also don't know what type of bearing to get.
Can you maybe point me toward a source?
Additionally, if you aren't using the board, where do you wire the motor for the extruder?
Thanks for any help.
comments.author: larrynotlawrence

comments.text:
This bearing will do ..... http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/603-629-Series-ZZ-Stainless-Steel-Sealed-Metric-Ball-Bearing-Choose-Size/331886640701?hash=item4d45fc3e3d:m:mizSYwHiQDOZ1gHNQoFN3WA
The extruder motor is wired directly to the harness from the mainboard.
You can find the wiring for the small PCB on the extruder here ...... http://www.soliforum.com/topic/10477/is-the-circuit-board-on-the-extruder-necessary/
comments.author: larrynotlawrence

comments.text:
Thank you very much for the quick reply. I will have to source the bearing somewhere else, however.
I can't possibly see paying $1.00 for it, but with $25 shipping! lol
comments.author: scobo

comments.text: Where did you put the board from the old extruder?
comments.author: ironjoe13

comments.text:
I removed it completely and wired the fan and thermistor directly to the harness.
There's no need for it with repetier.
Have a look here for the wiring ...... http://www.soliforum.com/topic/10477/is-the-circuit-board-on-the-extruder-necessary/
comments.author: ironjoe13

comments.text:
The conversion has begun.....
It looks like it doesn't hang as low as the original extruder, somewhat close to the carriage
comments.author: ironjoe13

comments.text:
Looking good there !
You actually loose a couple of mm in the z axis. I use a printed piece to adjust the z endstop.

Did you not get one of the silicone socks with your E3D ?

comments.text: yea it's a blue one. The E3D is new as well, so it's a complete overhaul
comments.author: scobo

comments.text: how do you clean your driver wheel do you take apart the spring assembely
comments.author: NoHands

comments.text:
I just use a small brush to clean it while the gear is turning. Don't have to do it that often though, it seems to be almost self cleaning.
I guess you could take the lever off if the gear was really clogged but I've never needed to do that in the year or so I've been using this setup.

title: Rancilio Rocky spout - doser to doserless conversion

description.text:
This model is all that you need to convert a doser Rancilio Rocky to a doserless model.

The doser model of the Rancilio Rocky is a pretty huge pain for home users. There will be a significant amount of coffee sitting in it between uses, and it adds an extra step to the grind process. I have since upgraded to a different machine, however thought this would be an interesting project.

When you remove the doser, however, there is now several mm of gap between the grind chamber and the outer metal frame, making it impossible to use that way.

I wanted to design a compression-fit component rather than dropping $30 on a spout and the "rubber spacer" needed from the doserless model.

It was measured and designed for my machine specifically. The outer body of the Rocky is completely separate from the functional interior, therefore each machine will have slightly different offsets and tolerances for the spout. That is why this model has non-uniform dimensions. You will likely need to adjust the model or do some light sanding to make it fit yours.

title: Wasatch Willy's Wylie Camera Slider for Timelapse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a basic slow moving slider for timelapse photography.

It is also a work in progress.

You will need access to a Laser Cutter and a 3D printer. The 3D printed parts are made with PLA at .2 layer height.

I used copper pipe rather than electrical conduit because of its smooth surface. I tried 1/2” copper pipe but it is not strong enough to support the weight of a DSLR over the 5’ distance. Eventually I will upgrade the design for a NEMA 17 Motor running from an Arduino that will also fire the camera. But right now this is as basic as I can make it using a very slowly moving .6 RPM motor. With a DSLR on the platform it will be under .5 RPM.

The shaft of the pulley is 6.05 mm and the pulley bore is 6.35 mm so I intend to wrap some metal tape around the shaft to make up the difference.
I used 1/4” MDF from HomeDepot and for the 3mm I bought a 3x7 foot sheet of 1/8th inch MDF that is white on one side.

Each end assembly has 6 pieces for the pipes to slip through. The end piece is engraved for the pipe to fit into. The middle piece has the hip joint for the leg. Then there is another piece for the pipe to slip through.

Assembling the legs. There are two of each leg. Stack them on top of each other and the line should befacing up on both pieces. Put a little glue on the small spacers and insert between the leg pieces. Insert a 1/4” bolt, washers and nut then tighten it down. Insert the larger spacers and bolt them together but do not glue them. They are only to help align the legs during assembly. When the glue is dried remove the bolts, you will use them to attach the legs.

Parts List:

MDF 1/4” or 6mm
MDF 1/8” or 3mm
12vdc Motor JSX5300-370 .6 rpm
Idler Pulley for 6mm GT-2 Belt
Pulley for 6.35mm Bore for GT-2 Belt
Copper Pipe 10’ - 3/4” Type M cut in half
3D Printed Linear Bearings (4)
Tripod Ball Head
1/4 x 20 Inserts (2)
Cable Tie (2) to attach Belt to platform
1/4”x20 x 1” Screws or bolts for legs (4)
1/4” washer (8)
1/4” Nuts (4)
3/8” Bolt for Tripod Ball Head (1)
3/8” Nut (2)
3D Printed Idler Spacers (2)
M3x8 Screws (4) Motor Mount

title: Parametric Needle Cutter Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Default settings should give a usable cutter mount that's about 20mm taller than djk4linux's orignal design based on his suggestion that a taller mount would probably work better due to putting less lateral force on the needle. So far this seems to be true.

I have a github repo for development on this if anyone wants to colaborate on improving it and/or adding more mount styles. https://github.com/jhitesma/parametric_needle_cutter

8/28/2016 - Finally found time to print one of my own and confirmed that at least with the default settings it works quite well. Original hicwic mount is now included and should work for most reasonable sizes - but the mount isn't parametric yet so it just kind of jumps between two sizes. Also haven't added the new default MPCNC mounts but I'm getting ready to upgrade my MPCNC so will probably add those soon.

Still very much a work in progress. No actual mounts included yet. Not printed yet.

Really only posted so I can get feedback from some people on here: http://forum.flitetest.com/showthread.php?24251-Cutting-foam-sheets-with-a-needle! about how it works as a customizer.

8/17/2016 - Uploaded revised .scad file with hicwic style QC mount and a few minor fixes.
8/17/2016 - Uploaded another revised .scad file fixing some issues with the QC mount. QC mount isn't smart enough to resize yet, but now sits level with the base and will add an extension for taller mounts.

comments.text:
My feeble attempt at designing a crosshead bearing design for this needle cutter
Reciprocating motion is now limited to a loop in the needle twisted above the bearing, the bearing has a 3mm hole for a small 3m screw to bind the needle into the bearing, all lateral movement for the most part should be eliminated and now motion should be limited to an inline reciprocating motion...similar to the design of really old and large diesel/steam ship engines

title: Bodum Bistro Coffee Grinder Container Lid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: For some reason Bodum sells replacement containers for their Bistro Burr Coffee Grinder, but not replacement lids, which means that if you lose the lid or just want another, you are hosed. I made up a compatible one, where the only changes from the original are to make it printable without supports. I printed it in 80A TPE from filaments.ca and it works great. I suggest something flexible since the rim is slightly larger than the container to squish on. I also made a little removable plug to keep the ground coffee a little fresher.

title: Udoo Dual & Quad Mini PC Case - Multiple Configuration Options - rev. 2.0 - Updated Nov.28

description.text:
This is a 3-part case for the Udoo computer and controller board with dual 40mm exhaust fans and HDD/SSD. Older versions are still available which offer alternative configurations. Make sure to grab parts from the same revision to ensure they all fit together.
See the updated Gallery pictures for revision 2 details. I recommend a bit of foam tape to pad/secure the HDD/SSD in the bottom case, extra room was left available. Remember to make sure you get 5V fans or you won't be able to use the onboard fan header. Revision 2 notes:
While there is room for a straight SATA connector to plug into a 2.5" HDD in the carrier below the board, there isn't enough room for a traditional clip in connector on the UDOO itself. I'm looking for a shorter alternative, but fitting a cover on that allows Arduino expansion boards to directly plug in over the top may require soldering the SATA connector wires directly to the pads on the board. Revision 1 notes:
My design allows the boards to be easily fitted without risk of damaging the numerous connectors and buttons. I have also added mounting tabs so the computer can easily be mounted to whatever project you're working on. There is a second top for the case right now that has extra openings for ribbon cables to pass through and I can easily add or customize the openings if requested. Future plans are to change the cooling fan layout and cable routing for HDD. I'll probably be extending the case a bit to move the cables inside as well as moving to dual exhaust fans on the opposite end from the microsd card slot so it can be easily accessed again.

  • Nov.28 update - Revision 2.0. added an extra base option "Case_bottom_v.2.0_basic" which is just a simpler model of the v.2.0 base with the vents for the exhaust fans and holes for the HDD carrier removed. This would be a better base for users with the Udoo Dual board who want a cleaner/easier to print case. Recommend using the top with extra holes to avoid any overheating

  • Nov.11 update - Revision 2.0. added extra lid with a bunch of extra holes and the HDD base which has some extra height to it so that 2 40mm exhaust fans can be mounted.

  • Nov.3 update - Revision 2.0. First release of the new design. Optimized for easy printing and active cooling. The number of vents on the lid has been reduced.

  • Oct.31 update - Added rudimentary 2.5" (laptop) HDD holder and new case bottom with fan mount and vent hole to let some of the fan air down into the HDD space. Will need to do a complete redesign to move the cables internal and reduce the fan footprint. With a SATA HDD, accessing the microsd won't be as necessary.

  • Oct.30 update - Changed front panel so half of openings is on bottom and half on top, this should eliminate the need to use support material making for some cleaner prints. Also enlarged the port openings around the micro-USB slots to improve cable fitment. Added optional base with 40mm fan mount.
    *** Case bottom with 40mm fan requires the fan to be removed to access microsd card, - it's a work in progress.

  • Oct.27 update - added cooling slots above WiFi, merged Dual and Quad Core designs, added some fillets to help printing without support material, and other refinements.

I printed these parts out on a modified Ultimaker in PLA (which is best for dimensional stability).   
Print setup is fairly straight forward, flat side down, bottom on bottom, and top on top. For the bottom part I found enabling retraction and no support worked quite well. For the top you may want to enable interior support because bridging the opening for the full-size USB and Ethernet ports may result in excess stringing.   
I've tried to filet all the openings to minimize the bridging distances.  
Contact me if you need some tweaks to the design made to better work with your printer.

Had to open up the holes for the power supply, the power and reset buttons a bit, but otherwise it's a nice case!

comments.author: RuschGaming

comments.text: I have printed the newest revision case for my quad and it works great. What size mounting screws is this designed for? I am currently using #4, which is close but not quite exact. The openings for the reset and power buttons are not quite lined up but they are still functional. Also, the Udoo only has a single fan header with a fairly low current output. Have you successfully connected two fans at the same time?  I plan on adding one for now to see how well it cools because the Udoo does get warm in the case without air flow.
comments.author: TopherT1

comments.text:
If the power and reset buttons are sitting a bit high in their holes, you might have a blob or your printer might not have duplicated the cutouts in the standoffs for the soldered pins right near the mounting points.
I found you need to pull power for multiple fans off one of the usb headers. The dedicated cpu fan connector barely runs a single fan. Hoping to return to this project once the new printer board is finished.
comments.author: TopherT1

comments.text: How were you able to get the onboard fan header working? Mine does not drive my 5V fan. The fan is functional, so I looked at the schematic and it has a fan_enable. How do you toggle that?
comments.author: jamessheridan88

comments.text: Not sure about the pin, it's been a bit since I looked into the fan issue. I know when I attempted to drive the dual fans off that connector it was unable to supply the required current. It's a super low power circuit. Let me give it another look tonight.
comments.author: jamessheridan88

comments.text: a few design problems with the 2.0 (Quad) case.
comments.author: flintols

comments.text: Do you want to post a picture of what you're talking about with the power/reset buttons ? I've tested the case with both a quad and a dual and the buttons are perfectly centered. It might be a bit of variation in how close to the board those switches are being soldered. I don't have the starter pack, so I'd probably need pictures & dimensions of the extra parts before I can incorporate them. For securing the HDD, I'm using a bit of foam double sided tape on either side of the drive to give it a bit of cushioning. It was going to be a snug fit, but I had to add some extra height to mount the fans. You'll probably need to use the top with the extra holes just so you can get the bend in the connector (and clearance) for the sata cable to plug into the board, this should give you access to the camera connector.

title: E14S Fast Electric Unicycle - new version!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE 14.11.2016:
See article with detailed instructions in MAKE magazine:
http://makezine.com/projects/3d-print-electric-unicycle/

This is an updated version of the E14D Electric Unicycle which I published earlier. My goal was to make a more compact version with better ergonomics but with the same impressive range and performance as its predecessor. This unicycle is also designed for the high performance 14" 500W Unicycle motor from Microworks, but it can be used with others as well.

The old version was designed to be used with up to 4 individual 16 cell battery packs, which were connected in parallel. Instead of 4 packs of 16 cells (16S1P), this new version uses 2 packs of 32 cells (16S2P), which makes it possible to make the battery housings significantly smaller but still with the same total capacity. Also, this version uses a horizontal controller which is located just underneath the handle, so the housings on both sides are now available for batteries.

The essential structure is the same as on the earlier version, the housings on both sides are identical and printed in two sections, which are then stacked and secured with M8 threaded rods which go through the whole structure from top to bottom. The housings on both sides are bolted to each other through the top handle part, also using two M8 threaded rods. A horizontally programmed mainboard can be placed in the space underneath the top handle. The upper nuts are now recessed and hidden inside the top covers. The 8mm bolt holes on the upper covers don´t go all the way through to the recessed nut, but there is 0.5mm of material left inbetween which needs to be drilled out. This is simply because the print result is better this way.

With the motor I used, top speed is around 30 km/h (can be limited by software to meet local legal requirements) and when using the maximum amount of battery capacity, your range should be around 40 km in actual road conditions.

I´ve been trying to keep the design as simple, compact and smooth as possible.

I recommend PLA for this project to avoid warping issues. You could also use PETG, which will be even stronger. No supports or rafts needed. Please be aware that these parts are large and will take a long time to print.

See videos:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A3gQpAUEFJo&feature=youtu.be
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UAJHFsctif8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TBEu8ykEiAg

Assembly parts needed:

  • 2 rolls (à 1 kg) of PLA (or PETG) filament

  • M8 threaded rods:
    4x 225mm length
    2x 60mm length

  • 12x M8 nuts (13mm, nylocks recommended, you could also use cap nuts for four of them on the top covers)
  • 8x M8 washers
  • 12x M5 screws, approx. 12mm long (heads as flat as possible)
  • 12x M5 washers
    The M8 rods&nuts could be replaced with an American thread of similar size (5/16?), but make sure that the openings for the upper nuts will fit. They are made for 13mm sized nuts, so the opening is 13.5mm. The shorter rods which are used to bolt together the handle and the two upper sections of the battery housings are less critical regarding nut size.
    The M5 threaded screws cannot be replaced as they are used on the pedal assembly which has metric threads.

Parts to be ordered (mine came from Shenzen Microworks, they can be found on alibaba):

  • 14” 500W high speed motor
  • standard 14”x2.125 or wider 14"x2.5 tire & inner tube
  • 30B4 high speed controller with bluetooth module, please ask for horizontal programming! That will make it possible to mount the controller flat on top. You can also use a regular vertical controller, but you will then need to use one of the battery housings to accomodate the controller so you will only be able to use half of the potential battery capacity.
  • pedals and assembly parts
  • power switch, charging socket, LED-battery indicators, HAL-cables

Batteries:

  • 2x 60 Volt 16S2P unicycle battery with 32 cells for maximum range and capacity (you can use the regular 16 cell batteries which are easier to find, but they will have only half the capacity, which is still not bad if you use two of them). Check the dimensions of the batteries (maximum thickness 43mm, max width 142mm. max height 160mm) and make sure they will fit before you buy them. It is a tight fit.
  • 1 x 67 Volt generic unicycle battery charger

Other parts:

  • 1-2 piezo buzzers (you can decide whether to use just one or one on each side)

IMPORTANT: MAKE ABSOLUTELY SURE BOTH BATTERIES HAVE EXACTLY THE SAME VOLTAGE BEFORE CONNECTING THEM IN PARALLEL! ALSO, DURING ASSEMBLY MAKE SURE THAT NO METAL PARTS ARE IN DIRECT CONTACT WITH THE BATTERY! DO NOT WORK ON LITHIUM BATTERIES UNLESS YOU ARE ABSOLUTELY SURE YOU KNOW WHAT YOU ARE DOING, UNDERSTAND THE RISKS AND TAKE ALL NECESSARY PRECAUTIONS! ANYTHING YOU DO HAPPENS AT YOUR OWN RISK!

UPDATE 13.10.2016:

Following updates have been made to the files:

  1. Screw locations on the pedal brackets have been adjusted to match the latest version of the pedal holder from Microworks.
  2. Upper covers have been changed to fit the latest version of the LED battery indicators from MIcroworks (LEDs directly on PCB)
  3. Battery housings have been slightly widened on the inside to easier fit 32 cell packs on both sides (43.5mm width).
  4. The space for the controller board underneath the handle has been made slightly higher.
  5. Both halves of the battery housings have been made slightly higher, adding just enough clearance to also use a wider 14x2.5" tire instead of the regular 14x2.125". The outer diameter of the 14x2.5" tire will in fact make this a 15" unicycle.

This unicycle shell can now also be used with 16" motors if you use the following spacer, which can be added between upper and lower section of the battery housing to increase overall height:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1834059

9.11.2016:
Now you can also add some fenders with or without integrated headlight:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1879793

PLEASE SHARE YOUR MAKE IF YOU DECIDE TO PRINT THIS ITEM!

CREATING AND FINALIZING THIS ELECTRIC UNICYCLE HAS TAKEN SEVERAL WEEKS OF DESIGNING, TESTING, MODIFICATIONS AND MORE THAN A DOZEN TEST VERSIONS TO GET ALL THE PARTS RIGHT AND TO MAKE THEM FIT PERFECTLY. PLEASE CONSIDER LEAVING A TIP VIA THINGIVERSE IF YOU FIND THIS ITEM USEFUL.

comments.text:
I tried to make one myself. building upon the ninebot one e plus hardware. give it a go, waste some plastic :D

comments.author: EUGUY

comments.text:
Hi, I have started printing the pedal brackets but they fail on the last 20% where the nozzle starts to print off the object. I have a Prusa I3 Mk2 and seems to work with other prints. Have you heard of this problem or do you think it is a printer problem. I am using 60% infill.
Thank you, Phil
comments.author: Phil500

comments.text:
Hi Phil,
sorry to hear that. No, I haven´t heard of such problem. I myself have printed at least 8 of those pedal brackets, half of them on an i3 clone and there have never been any problems and I also know of several other people who have successfully printed it. Have you checked that there are no mechanical issues with your printer at that height, which could cause for a belt to jump? What slicing software are you using? You could try using a different one.

comments.text: Where did you order the batteries you used from - or do you know what dimensions they need to be?
comments.author: E-Mat

comments.text: I made the battery packs myself, using a 16S BMS board from aliexpress (size 136x148mm) and samsung cells from gearbest. I used two cells connected in parallel in each spot. The dimensions of most16S BMS boards are almost identical, so if you buy some factory made batteries, they are probably more compact than what I was able to accomplish. The most critical dimension is the maximum thickness, which should not exceed 43mm. Maximum width is 143mm which should be more than enough, height can be up to 155 mm or even a bit more, so no problems there either.
comments.author: Kanedias

Original Beelink BT7's case (http://www.bee-link.com/Beelink-MiniPC-TV-BOX-37-1.html) have several issues with cooling, the very tiny fan (30x30mm) is not able to cool down the temperature of the entire system even in daily use arriving up to 90° very easily (Tjunction of Intel Atom Z8700 is 90 celsius) causing throttling and instalibility of the computer.

I've built a case in PLA with my 3D printer, added a 80x80mm fan and a support for a 2.5" drive, like an SSD.

Now the cpu does not exceed 75 ° on the hottest core after 4 hours of Prime95 stress test.

The entire system draws 5w in idle, 8w with 4K/30FPS x264 movie rendering, and 10w under maximum stress.

To make the frame, buy a threaded rod m4 and divide into 4 pieces 8cm approx.

Other photos: https://goo.gl/photos/CKQ5g47RKTDsFvf8A

This is a parametric version of FdS' flex-box.  
You can edit the file using your favorite text editor (notepad, vi, emacs, pico) to change the height, width, and length of the box.  Then send the file to your laser cutter and you will have yourself an awesome little box.  
edit: v 1.1 some clean-up and bug fixes  
v 1.2 hopefully squashed that bug  
v 1.3 fixed an issue with long decimal numbers

• Download flexbox.ps and open it in your favorite text editor (notepad will work great for this)
  • Find the section that defines the box parameters:
    • boxlength
    • boxwidth
    • boxheight
  • Change the size of the box to suit your needs, these are the outside dimensions of the box
  • Save the file then open it in your graphics program, I've had luck with CorelDraw here
  • Send the file to your laser cutter
    • I cut this box out of 1/8" plywood, on a 35 watt laser running at 100% power, 0.5%speed
  • Assemble your box, revel in the fact that the once stiff plywood bends corners to make an attractive box you would give to your friend or even consider keeping for yourself

I bought a motopilot for my motorcycle, whichs uses tomtom maps and I wanted to use it in the car as well - but there is no car mount from Blaupunkt for it!
So I looked in my junk box and found this swan neck mount with suction cup. Then I designed a bracket, that just clips on. There is a blank version too, if you want to remix it for a ram mount, vent mount etc.

For a good fit glue a bit of cloth on the bottom on the inside - I used a part of the soft side of a hook-and-pile strip.

Within the first test I realized, that the sound of the motopilot is to low in a louder car. The speaker is on the rear side of the navi, so I designed the enhancement, that reflects the sound to the front. In this way it amplifies the spoken words a bit.

You can print each part on its own and then glue them.
Or print both as one piece. Then you will need support.

I added several versions:

motopilot.stl - the bracket with a slot for "my" swan neck / suction cup
motopilot_blank.stl - for remixing (air vent adapter, ram mount ...)
speaker.stl - sound enhancement
motopilot_with_speaker.stl - the bracket with a slot for "my" swan neck / suction cup + speaker as one part
motopilot_blank_with_speaker.stl - for remixing + speaker as one part
motopilot5_with_speaker.FCStd - FreeCad-File

IMPORTENT: Use ABS because it can get very hot behind the windshield of a car in summer.

title: Fake Wii Nunchuck Game Controller Nunchuck Accessory

description.text:
I WILL NOT BE IMPROVING THIS MODEL. It prints, but it's not terribly accurate. See photo next to real one.

I want a kind of organic ergonomic controller kind of like a Wii Nunchuck. Before I totally mangled it, I thought I'd upload what I have so far. I haven't printed it, but it would be straightforward as a prop/decoration.

This is actually a really poor representation if you're looking for accuracy. Buttons are the wrong size, thumbstick is too far back, end is skinny, curvature is wrong... but it's probably close enough for a decoration or the like.

I provided a solid version and a hollow version.

I'm sharing even though its rough because I found it nearly impossible to find a 3D Nunchuck model.

This is a heavily modified remix of an unknown file without attribution that I stumbled across. I'd be happy to add attribution if someone claims it.

title: Recreus extruder blower fan mount and shroud
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I use a recreus extruder and there aren't many (as far as I've seen at least) fan mounts/shrouds for the particular extruder. So here goes a funky design which works really well. The fit will have to do with the hot end you are using, in any case I hope someone finds this useful. I have attached a design I did of the recreus extruder to help with aligning the parts (or use it to design your own parts on it) The blower fan shell was designed by Anil Anand and can be found "https://grabcad.com/library/blower-fan-8".

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25

Notes:

To print without supports you'll need active cooling. I print the shroud vertically with the blower mount end on the bottom, I use a raft for it because due to the small size of the inner rectangle it sometimes detaches from the bed.
(sorry for the angle :) Shroud fan mount, it just clicks on (sorry for the angle) Attached and working great. (sorry for the pic angle)

Shroud Design

Using Fusion 360 I created 4 rectangles for the blower fan mount end, extruded them and filleted the corners. Then I created some offset planes a few centimeters ahead of them and created a few circles to the shape of the shroud. Using loft I created 3 shapes (for the 3 different air vents) and merged the 3 bodies. Then I offset the original loft shapes to a smaller size and used loft to create 3 similar but smaller shapes. I merged the 3 shapes, and cut them from the original/larger body and was left with the final shroud.

title: Kossel - mechanical switch mount for nylon autoleveling effector

description.text:
I ordered a nylon effector with autoleveling option. However, there was no instructions on attaching the switch. Therefore, I designed a simple mount for mechanical switch for this effector.

This is designed for Omron SS-5GL mechanical switch.

There is also other versions for this same effector:

  • for optical switch http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1191506
  • for mechanical switch http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1310401

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

I printed this upside down and 2 pieces at the same time (due to small item and lacking cooling).

I printed this without supports. Only location that might print better with supports are the vertical holes.

I fastened the switch and mount utilizing M2x20 screws, washers and nuts.

A spring was added for more reliable return to normal position of the effector.

The metal strip of the switch was cut a bit shorter in order to increase the space between the strip and spring.

New 2.5mm hole for the M3x20 switch triggering screw was made to the effector (see the last image). This was done to move the triggering spot a bit closer to the trigger's "button" and decrease the impact of bending of the metal strip of the switch.

In addition to the nylon effector and the screws that came along it took:

  • 4pcs M2x20 screws (2 for switch-mount, 2 for mount-effector)
  • 8pcs M2 washers
  • 4pcs M2 nuts
  • 1pc M3x20 screw (for triggering the switch)
  • 1pc 5.5x38mm spring (that was cut a bit shorter)

description.text:
This is not a complete airsoft gun it is just the shell of a bullpup airsoft gun you will need to design you own internals to hold the gearbox and magazine.

It is designed in two halves a left and right each half is broken up into three pieces and an end to fit on a 20x20x20 cm build plate. The three side pieces glue together and the two halves screw together with 13 m3 x 16mm screws. The picatinny rails and silencer are just glued on when the gun is finished.

If you have any questions or want to see more pics please feel free to ask and I will try and help.

description.text:
Curtain's ring, made to be sewn directly to the curtains. (nothing else needed). 38mm inside diameter. The gap for the tissue is 1mm, but can be from 0 to 3mm.
There are not round bore, but rounded hexagon bore to be printed on any printer without support. Raft is not requiered. They are strong enough even in PLA quite empty for 3m long curtains, one ring every 30 cm.
Works very fine with 28mm rod, but should work below too.
I also prepared a 9 rings file to fit 200x200mm² plates.

I also provide support for the 28mm rod, which makes a full curtains kit, if you already have a 28mm rod and fabric.

Printer:

dagoma discovery200

Resolution:

doesn't matter (I did 0.2)

Infill:

doesn't matter

Notes:

The resolution doesn't matter much (it's not made to be cut but useful), the sliding shouldn't change too much. It can be printed empty, just be sure the shape is thick enough.

Funnels are useful for so many things. Apparently a square shaped funnel empties faster than a conic funnel, so here's a parametric square funnel for you to mess with:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2eb1d3c3dd6b546404d676a4/w/b4788c6684d4abf213968330/e/5fd1788a98018322d9c7c5ab

I exported an example with both 1.5 and 0 shell thickness (i.e. solid) so you can choose whether to print this as a solid or a vase.
Tweaked the original model to make the inner hole a bit bigger, seems to bind less for me anyway.

description.text:
Wartortle
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Wartortle (カメール Kamēru, Kameil), known as the Turtle Pokémon, is the evolved form of Squirtle. It has a slightly more intimidating appearance than its preceding form; aside from an increased height and weight, it now has darker skin, eyes with smaller pupils, and two protruding fangs. Its shell may receive scars from battles that these Pokémon seek out.[45] A Wartortle also gets a pair of feathery ears, and its tail becomes white, fluffy, and too long to completely hide within its shell;[46] these appendages greatly aid this Pokémon in swimming, acting as oars and/or fins.[47] The tail also happens to be a highly valued collectors' item, which has caused people to hunt this Pokémon, dwindling their numbers. The reason for such poaching may very well be that a Wartortle tail is a symbol of longevity in the Pokémon world, supposedly allowing the creature to live for thousands of years.[48]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Wartortle

title: XYZ daVinci Jr - E3D V6/Lite6 Mount

description.text:
DO THIS ON YOUR OWN RISK!!!
I'm not responsible if you manage to fry your printer, any parts or even your house.
Use common sense when wiring and mounting things.
Never leave printer going unattended.
If you haven't done anything like that in the past for don't have required knowledge of electronics - DON'T DO IT!

If you do agree with what I've said - feel free to download.
If you disagree - click on magic X button and print some Yoda head (which is quite nice actually)

This is E3D v6/Lite6 mount for XYZ Printing daVinci Jr.
It's suppose to go in stock Jr, no RAMPS mod is required or so (obviously if you've done one it will work as well).

To get it up and running you'll need obviously E3D v6/Lite6 gated itself and print Mount and Clip STL's.
(To fix Clip in place you can use existing Jr printhead screws which holds fan in place.)
You can use heatsink fan which goes with E3D hotend but I've printed this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:839620 to have print cooling fan as well and used existing Jr hotend fan (only flipped so it blows onto the hotend instead of pulling it)

I've printed it vertically to give some extra strength for the mount and hive smooth finish to the airflow channel.
Also printed with PLA but ABS obviously would be better hence the temperatures.
Been running it good 12-14hours a day for the past 2x weeks and had no problems what so ever.

Last thing you need to do is to relocate printhead PCB somewhere off the X gantry and wire everything up.
Jr is using the same 100k resistor as E3D so no mods to that are needed - just wire everything directly.

Problems with current design. Ok, it's not really a problem, it's more like small miscalculation.
With E3D in place you need to go to Z axis offset and add roughly 2mm, depend from your bed level.
I'll probably fix this in future versions but for now it's not a problem.

In my to do list I have:

  1. Design little PCB mount which are held on 2020 extrusion somewhere.
  2. Add cable clamps so I can nicely trace cables from hotend to the bowden tube.
  3. Design little cable organiser on the PCB end but that'll probably be part of the PCB mount/case.

Thing's what I'm not planning to do:

  1. Adopt this design to E3D's clone hotends (1st they are not worth the money quality wise, 2nd hotend build quality isn't there so don't be surprised if by saving £20 you'll burn down your house which I presume is worth more that £20)
  2. Adopt this design to any other hotend manufacturer, I just don't have any of them at hand.
  3. Build all in one mount + cooling fan. This open design is whole reason why I said bye to Jr "boxed" design approach.

Things I do consider:

  1. Do direct drive iteration of this design so I can print flexible materials much more easier.
    Only setback for this is that 1st I need to redesign X axis mount at the right. It not going to cary extra stepper early without sagging even more.

Printer:

XYZ Printing da Vinci Jr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print it vertically.

title: Belt sized Pokeball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A pokeball used for Cosplaying your own trainer!

Can be attached to belt using your preferred method: velcro, hairtie loop, magnets, whatever your mind can think of.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Z18

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1-.2

Infill:

any

Notes:

Print ball center in black, button in gray or white, and ball top in whatever colors you want for top & bottom of ball. Alignment tool is completely optional.

I print with a raft since they print better, but you can safely do so without depending on your build plate. Support should not be necessary.

Assembly

After printing, decide how to attach balls to belt (if applicable) and whether or not to use alignment tool. For my attachment method I used my soldering iron to poke a small hole at the back of ballcenter, then glued a stretchy hairtie halfway through hole.

If using the alignment tool, snap it onto ball center first using the long insert to center the tool through the button hole and then make sure arms are mostly centered/parallel. Press both ball tops against tool, making sure to center button cutouts, and pull off one half. Use superglue along center & top seam to secure one half. Remove tool and glue in button. For other half, use reverse side of tool to keep spacing consistent and spread glue along top edge of center, Align button cutout with other half and press other ball half together.

Enjoy your new pokeballs!

title: All Pokemons (Will be updated with new pokemons)

description.text:
Pokémon
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
For other uses, see Pokémon (disambiguation).

Pokémon (ポケモン Pokemon?, /ˈpoʊkeɪˌmɒn/ or /ˈpoʊkᵻˌmɒn/ - poh-kay-mon or poh-ki-mon)[1][2] is a media franchise managed by The Pokémon Company, a Japanese consortium between Nintendo, Game Freak, and Creatures.[3] While the franchise copyright is shared by all three companies, Nintendo is the sole owner of the trademark.[4] The franchise was created by Satoshi Tajiri in 1995,[5] and is centered on fictional creatures called "Pokémon", which humans, known as Pokémon Trainers, catch and train to battle each other for sport.

The franchise began as a pair of video games for the original Game Boy, developed by Game Freak and published by Nintendo. The franchise now spans video games, trading card games, animated television shows and movies, comic books, and toys. Pokémon is the second-most successful and lucrative video game-based media franchise in the world, behind only Nintendo's Mario franchise.[6]

Cumulative sales of the video games (including home console games, such as Hey You, Pikachu! for the Nintendo 64) have reached more than 200 million copies.[7] In November 2005, 4Kids Entertainment, which had managed the non-game related licensing of Pokémon, announced that it had agreed not to renew the Pokémon representation agreement. Pokémon USA Inc. (now The Pokémon Company International), a subsidiary of Japan's Pokémon Co., now oversees all Pokémon licensing outside of Asia.[8] As of May 2016, the Pokémon media franchise has grossed revenues of ¥4.8 trillion worldwide[9] (equivalent to 46.2 billion USD).

The franchise celebrated its tenth anniversary in 2006.[10] The twentieth anniversary was celebrated with a commercial at the 2016 Super Bowl[11] using the theme: "I can do that". 2016 marks the 20th anniversary of the release of the original games, with the company celebrating by airing an ad during Super Bowl 50, and issuing re-releases of Pokémon Red, Blue, and Yellow.[12][13] The mobile augmented reality game Pokémon Go was released in July 2016.[14] The next generation games Pokémon Sun and Moon are expected to be released in November 2016.[15] A live-action film adaptation based on Great Detective Pikachu is planned to start production in 2017.[16] The English slogan for the franchise is "Gotta Catch 'Em All".[17][18]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon

this was using acetone vapor .
it is a fast process
i have a asparagus pot (tall with a basket inside)
on stove a tablespoon of acetone
in basket a small metal disc (top of a can etc)
plastic on top of disc in basket

heat and watch the "wetness" as acetone condenses on the plastic
usually less than 1 minute depending on item height.
remove basket let dry for a few minutes

print_settings.Notes:: The clip is a little tricky.  I printed it on it's side in order to get nice straight sides, but the little circular nubs along the back came out kind of oblong shaped and required trimming to fit into the case.  You could try printing this with the nubs down, but then the inside of the clip will be full of support material.  Play around with it I guess.  Once you get it to fit into the holes in the case, superglue it in place - I glued mine around the nubs and around the perimeter of the clip.  No issues so far.

description.text:
Just a simple case for the Zune Flash player (2nd gen). My 7 year old leather case was looking a little, uh, rough. This case features a clip that the top to hold the Zune in place. The bottom is completely open to allow easy access to both ports. The Zune fits pretty snugly in place, so you may have to adjust the dimensions a bit (depending on your 3D printer's accuracy).

I also made a basic clip for it, kind of as an afterthought, so it isn't the best set up, but it works. Just press it into the back and superglue it in place.

Print the case with the back side down.

The clip is a little tricky. I printed it on it's side in order to get nice straight sides, but the little circular nubs along the back came out kind of oblong shaped and required trimming to fit into the case. You could try printing this with the nubs down, but then the inside of the clip will be full of support material. Play around with it I guess. Once you get it to fit into the holes in the case, superglue it in place - I glued mine around the nubs and around the perimeter of the clip. No issues so far.

Metapod
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Metapod (トランセル Toranseru, Toranseu), known as the Cocoon Pokémon, are pupal Pokémon found in the wild early in the Kanto and Johto regions, of which its larval form is the caterpillar-like Caterpie. They can evolve into the butterfly-like Butterfree. While Metapod is classified as a cocoon Pokémon, it bears more resemblance to a chrysalis. A Metapod's exterior is regularly hardened to protect its soft and tender innards while undergoing metamorphosis to eventually become a Butterfree.[74] To conserve energy for this event, the Metapod barely moves.[75] While this shell is said to be as hard as steel, a large sudden impact could cause its vulnerable body to pop out, leaving it completely exposed.[76]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Metapod

Caterpie
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Caterpie (キャタピー Kyatapī), known as the "worm" Pokémon,[54] was designed by Ken Sugimori.[55] Satoshi Tajiri, creator of the series, took heavy inspiration from his childhood hobby of insect collection in creating the various Pokémon species.[56] Caterpie was based on the design of a caterpillar, specifically the caterpillar of the Swallowtail butterfly.[57] Caterpie's name is also derived from the word caterpillar.[58] Caterpie have green skin with a yellow underbelly, yellow spots, and large red osmeterium protruding from their foreheads.[59] Their green bodies are useful for camouflage in foliage,[60] their eyes are patterned to scare away predators,[61] their suction-cup feet allow them to climb any surface,[62] and the osmeterium on their heads can project a horrid stench to repel predators.[63] Caterpie is the smallest of all the original Pokémon,[64] and grows in size by shedding its skin.[54] Caterpie evolves into Metapod, and eventually Butterfree.[65] Prior to Pokémon Platinum, It could only ever learn two attacks, Tackle and String Shot, and is severely limited in ability until it evolves.[59]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Caterpie

Butterfree
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Butterfree (バタフリー Batafurī), known as the Butterfly Pokémon, are fully developed, butterfly-like Pokémon that have hatched from their pupal Metapod forms. Butterfree resembles a vaguely anthropomorphic butterfly. Unlike true insects, it only has four legs, which are a pale blue color. It has a nose-like structure which is a similar color. Its body’s coloration is a darker purple-blue. It has large veined wings which are white with black markings. These markings can help distinguish male and female individuals. It has large compound eyes which tend to be a reddish color. Butterfree feed on honey from flowers, and they rub the honey onto the hairs on their legs to transport the honey back to their nests.[77] Like members of the order Lepidoptera, Butterfree’s wings are covered in fine scales that are water-repellant and allow it to fly in heavy rains,[78] something many other insect Pokémon such as Masquerain cannot do, and are also coated in toxic dust that can be directed at an opponent in battle through wing-flapping.[79]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Butterfree

Kakuna
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Kakuna (コクーン Kokūn, Cocoon), known as the Cocoon Pokémon, are pupal Pokémon found in the Kanto and Johto regions, of which its larval form is the worm-like Weedle. They can evolve into the hornet-like Beedrill. Kakuna is a yellow, cone-shaped cocoon Pokémon. Kakuna has a dome-shaped head and black, triangular eyes. Within the shell, a Kakuna busily prepares itself for evolution into its adult form, and the amount of energy released by this process makes the shell hot to the touch.[88] Kakuna can use a poisonous sting to defend themselves if disturbed.[89]

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Kakuna

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Weedle (ビードル Bīdoru, Beedle), known as the Hairy Bug Pokémon, are larval Pokémon found in the wild early in the Kanto and Johto regions. They are very weak Pokémon that are captured to be evolved into their cocoon-like Kakuna form and eventually into the hornet-like Beedrill form. Weedle have little pink feet and a pink, round nose. Commonly spotted in the forests and grasslands, eating leaves, Weedle are well-protected from predators by sharp two-inch barbs on their heads[80] which secrete a strong poison, and another stinger is on each Weedle's rear. Sniffing with its big red proboscis, a Weedle uses its extremely acute sense of smell to find the types of leaves it eats.[81] Often living in forests and grasslands,[82] it eats its weight in leaves every day.[83]

Edit: Added the necessary parts for no YAW configuration.
Updated the Base for the no YAW configuration (3 Screw Halls)

Bladeless Fan With yaw
This is provided as is. I haven't tried printing it.

Parts:

  1. Control Circuitry (Arduino (Mini, Pro mini, etc, or any other micro)
    with IR sensor or wifi or bluetooth for remote control (No buttons on the device)
    If you want to have Yaw control, otherwise can can just plug in power and it will turn on
  2. Small DC motor
    3.Small servo max height 17mm (Needed only if you want yaw)
  3. 2x 688-2rs ball bearings (Version with YAW)
  4. Dc Power Jack (panel mount)
  5. 90mm Fan blade (Optional: 3D printable vesrion available
  6. Screws and bolts
  7. Glue

A resized version of the following blade is available
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:966444

Instructions

0a. Print all the necessary parts
If you want to have YAW control Print the "Servo-mount(Version-with-YAW).stl"
If you don't want YAW control print the "No-Yaw-extra-parts.stl"
0b. Polish them (or not)

With YAW:

  1. Take the DC motor and Screw it to the motor Mount.
  2. Take the servo and Screw it to the servo mount
  3. Take the servo Assembly and screw it on the bottom (The level one) side of the base housing facing down
  4. Take The motor Assembly and screw it on the top side of the base housing facing up
  5. Take the Fanblade and put it on the motor
  6. Take the ball bearings and place them on the "safts" on the inside of the Base housing and use screws with a small flange to keep them in place
  7. Take the DC jack Printed part and Glue it to the Base(where there is a moon circle)
  8. Take your DC Jack and solder the wires to it and the place it in the DC Jack part
  9. Take the base and screw to the servo
  10. Find Plug your servo to the arduino and find find the 2 extremes where it doesn't hit anything(or use limit switches)
  11. Place your control Circuitry somewhere in the Base housing (somewhere were you can reach it to program it in the future)
  12. Route the cables from the DC jack, Servo, DC motor to the Control cirtuit and make sure they don't interfere.
  13. Program your control Circuitry and run a test.
  14. Glue the Inner Housing to the Outer Housing
    and then to the Base housing.

Without YAW:

  1. Take the DC motor and Screw it to the motor Mount.
  2. Take The motor Assembly and screw it on the top side (the Uneven one) of the base housing facing up
  3. Take the Fanblade and put it on the motor
  4. Take the no yaw extra parts Screw the the long part and screw it to one size of the Base Housing
  5. Take the Ball bearing replacements from the extra parts and place them on the "safts" on the inside of the Base housing and use screws with a small flange to keep them in place
  6. Take the DC jack Printed part and Glue it to the Base(where there is a moon circle)
  7. Take your DC Jack and solder the wires to it and the place it in the DC Jack part
  8. Take the base and screw to the Base Housing and the Long part of the Extra parts
  9. Place your control Circuitry somewhere in the Base housing (somewhere were you can reach it to program it in the future)
  10. Route the cables from the DC jack, DC motor to the Control cirtuit and make sure they don't interfere.
  11. Program your control Circuitry and run a test.
  12. Glue the Inner Housing to the Outer Housing
    and then to the Base housing.

description.text:
A Glow in the Dark Destiny from Stargate Universe(SGU)
Or our artistic interpretation of it..O:)
An ode to a magnificent series that felt the wrath of kapitalism.
A little support to the fans. Enjoy. Maybe, juust maybe, the crew will wake up one day ;)

Printer:

Felixprinter 2.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Cura slicer In Repetier Host, load and scale to 0.0035, printed with 0.35mm nozzle. support; touching bed. printed upwards.

Removing supports

If in Repetier host, in tab slicer,
and pressing the "configuration" bttn when Cura slicer is selected, you get
the cura settings. upper tab print/filament
under print tab you go to the "structures" tab and under "support"
set the xy distance to 0.6 and Zdistance to
0.15 if 0.15 is your layer height,
0.2 if 0.2 is your layer height.
Then, removing supports should be a breeze.

The Origin

The Destiny is a brainchild of Brad Wright and Robert C Cooper who wrote Stagate Universe. It is a faster then light interstellar spaceship with a stargate onboard, and various economic and military capabilities.
This Destiny is drawn by one of our fellow 3D Warehouse members on Sketchup. Due to a sudden rise of models, and artists, we cannot exactly remember from whoem. Though to give credit then, But we only adapted it for 3D Printing, wich means exporting, and making manifold, wich was quite a task on such a big model. it needs to be scaled to 0.0035(+/-) of the original scale to fit on a 20x20 bed.

the Tip of the ship

the Tip of the ship gets too hot and can melt away. you can sove this by adding cooling or making the printhead move more for ex; Print two destiny's from the same height. tip one gets a lot more time to dissapate heat due to the head having to print the exact same thing a bit further.

comments.text: Hi, im trying to print a large one of these but i cant figure out how to slice it into smaller sections so that it will fit onto my print bed?
comments.author: victorsanders

comments.text:
123D Make can do it, but autodesk is discontinuing those apps, so;
Download Free Autodesk Meshmixer
Open your model in it
Go to "Vieuw>Show Object Browser" or ctrl+shift+o
the object browser appears,
there's a symbol that looks like two rounded squares overlapping, clicking it will copy your selected model on the spot.
copy the models as many times as you want parts; for ex; if you want to divide the model in four, you need to end up with one original & four copy's(you can also duplicate the original with each part you make to save pc memory)
you Can go to "Edit>Transform" and move it, but that will make our job harder.
you have now two identical models
select one in the Object Browser, and go to "Edit>Plane Cut"
green , red and blue arrows and bows allow you to aim your cut.
because the models you copied are occupying the same space, you can view your cut while looking at another copy.
click the eye-symbol in the object browser to toggle the visibility of each copy.
This way you can cut the whole part like you want.
Meshmixer can feel weird when you work it the first time, but youtube can help a lot with conrols.
Main thing to remember is to keep right mousebttn pressed to look around, scroller to zoom, and use "c" to re-orient your vieuw to the point your cursor is pointing, at the time you press the "c". Have fun....

title: Z Support for Hictop Prusa I3

description.text:
I was having a few problems with the Z smooth rod sometimes being pulled/shaken out from my Hictop Prusa I3 during a print, which was allowing the X assembly to shake which would ultimately end up ruining prints.

I decided to design this part which securely hold the M8 rod with a screw which clamps the part to the rod and connects to the motor mounts with existing screw holes.

I wrote a small blog post about this at https://mkdev.co.uk/z-rod-support-hictop-prusa/

Printer:

Hictop Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used 100% infill to ensure the part was super strong, However I'd recommend at minimum 70%
This was designed using tinkercad.

comments.text: I'm using a Hictop Prusa i3, nearly a year old now.  It's kind of an abomination of upgrades now.  Azteeg X5 mini with the 5984 stepper drivers are the latest upgrade which is why i'm going through the firmware.  I was reading about lead screws yesterday, that may be next on the upgrade list!
comments.author: Mcknight

comments.text: Awesome you probably have the same exact machine as me. So i'm guessing you have problems with the Z steps. If I were you I'd calibrate it manually with a digital caliper, you can pick them up for £10 if you don't already have one.
comments.author: Achoo01

comments.text: I do have digital calipers,  I measured my pitch to be 1.25mm,  I was able to get it working last night fairly well actually.
comments.author: Mcknight

comments.text: My bed does wobble a little on the Y, I have managed to solved this a bit before by tightening up the Y belts. My X/Z are perfectly stable though.
comments.author: Achoo01

comments.text: I got my y axis issue solved I think,  it looks good.  A little wobble but I don't think it really has an impact.  I'm printing a benchy right now at .1000 and now that everything else is calibrated well I can see the striations really really well.  They look identical in length to my M8 rod pitch, i'll have to play around with those and if no dice look into some lead screws like you have.
comments.author: Mcknight

comments.text: Cool, You'll have to let me know how you get on. :)
comments.author: Achoo01

comments.text: How do you have your lead screw fit in your coupler?  Does it go all the way in and touch the motor shaft, meet half way, or leave a gap between the two and let it flex?

Pidgey
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Pidgey (ポッポ, Poppo), known as the Tiny Bird Pokémon, resembles a small, plump-bodied bird. It is a brown color, with a lighter colored throat and belly. The tips of its wings share this cream color. Both its feet and beak are a pinkish-gray color. Its plumage is fairly nondescript, particularly compared to its evolutions Pidgeotto and Pidgeot. It has black markings around its eyes and a small crest of brown and cream feathers above its eyes. Pidgey are docile and prefer to avoid conflict. If disturbed, however, it can ferociously strike back[95] and will use its wings to stir up clouds of sand in an attempt to distract its would-be opponent and escape.[19] Pidgey also uses this technique to bring its preferred prey of small insects into the open.[96] Pidgey seems to possess magnetoception, as it is capable of returning to its nest from any location without fail.[97]

Pidgeotto
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Pidgeotto (ピジョン Pijon, Pigeon), known as the Bird Pokémon, is a larger and stronger form that Pidgey takes when it gains enough experience. It is a large raptor-like bird. While its primary color is brown, its plumage is much more elaborate than its pre-evolution, Pidgey. Its head-crest is much longer than Pidgey's and is a reddish color. The plumage of its tail is also quite colorful, alternating between red and yellow. Other than its ornamental plumage, its basic coloration is similar to Pidgey, with pinkish-gray feet and black markings around its eyes. Pidgeotto is extremely territorial, generally claiming a large area with its nest built in the center. Full of vitality, it constantly patrols its territory, mercilessly attacking intruders. They fly about in circular patterns while hunting, and can spot the movements of their prey on the ground no matter how high they fly.[100] Pidgeotto attacks with its wickedly sharp talons and carries its prey, including Exeggcute and Magikarp, back to its nest from as far as 60 miles away or more.[101] Pidgeotto appeared in the Pokémon anime as one of series star Ash Ketchum's first Pokémon. It eventually evolved into Pidgeot.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Pidgeotto

Pidgeot
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Pidgeot (ピジョット Pijotto, Pigeot), known as the Bird Pokémon, is the fully grown and developed form of the Pidgey species evolution line. Pidgeot is noticeably larger than its pre-evolution. Its plumage tends to be larger and glossier. The feathers on its head-crest are nearly as long as its body, and are yellow and red. Its tail feathers are red colored. Like its previous evolutions, its underbelly is a tan color, and it has black markings around its eyes. With their powerful chest muscles at work, Pidgeot can flap their wings fast enough to whip up gusts of winds to rival tornadoes.[102] Pidgeot are very aerodynamic, capable of soaring to an altitude of 3300 feet[103] and reaching speeds of up to Mach 2.[104] Like Pidgeotto, Pidgeot feed on Magikarp by swooping from the sky and snatching them out of the water with their talons.[103] Pidgeot appear very similar to Pidgeotto, so much so that one has been easily mistaken for the other, even by official sources.[105] Ash's Pidgeotto evolves into Pidgeot in the anime, and leaves his Pidgeot to protect its a group of Pidgey and Pidgeotto.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Pok%C3%A9mon_(1%E2%80%9351)#Pidgeot

description.text:
This is my version of air balloon powered car which I did for my kids. This idea is not mine and simillar models can be found here, but I did not like its design, so I did new one with old formula look. Balloon tube is sloped forward, because if it is not, balloon bends backwards and brakes the car.

Files are sorted by white and black. So print only separated parts. There are two variants or rims with 3 or 4 spokes, so you can choose what you like more.

== So STLs named "complete" are not for printing. That is just overview.==

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Rebel 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

Print was easy on my printer, with 0.2mm layer using PLA. Please use at least 3 perimeters because of top sheet consistency. Infill 20-25% should be enough.

Completing of the model

Rims are fitted by 2mm metric screws, which can be directly screwed into holes in body(without any drilling). Size of holes in rims are usually printed smaller, so use some tool to make it fit if you need. 4 spoke rims are printed with 2mm hole and 3 spoke with 2.75mm

Place for windshield is prepared in formula body and windshield should be secured by some drops of CA glue.
Design was done in Tinkercad

title: tiny crankbait.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
a tiny little crankbait lure, heavily inspired by this kind of design: http://www.ebay.com/itm/191613977629?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
but it seems like hundreds of chinese Ebay sellers have these.

the fillet tool really didn't cooperate on this one, but it's so small it doesn't really matter.

Update 20/8 -16
now i've actually went fishing with this little lure, and i can say that it works great!
i caught 11 perch and a half-decent pike on it that day.
but i also found a little problem with the design: it doesn't handle high speeds very well.
so keep that in mind. don't reel it in too fast, or i might start spinning out of control.
i may tinker a bit with the balance to see if i can fix it.

Printer:

Malyan M150 i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1-.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

print in PLA with 100% infill, and preferably a brim.

bend some .8mm steel wire into shape, add a hook and epoxy it together. and the main body is done! then you can decorate it however you want.
i went for a generic roach pattern with aluminium foil tape and permanent markers.
when that's done it might be a good idea to coat it in a layer of epoxy, or something. just to protect the paint.

great drawing, i know... it'll have to do.
